#Text=CHAPTER II .
#Text=Roderick
#Text=Early on the morrow Rowland received a visit from his new friend .
#Text=Roderick was in a state of extreme exhilaration , tempered , however , by a certain amount of righteous wrath .
#Text=He had had a domestic struggle , but he had remained master of the situation .
#Text=He had shaken the dust of Mr. Striker ’s office from his feet .
#Text=“ I had it out last night with my mother , ” he said .
#Text=“ I dreaded the scene , for she takes things terribly hard .
#Text=She does n’t scold nor storm , and she does n’t argue nor insist .
#Text=She sits with her eyes full of tears that never fall , and looks at me , when I displease her , as if I were a perfect monster of depravity .
#Text=And the trouble is that I was born to displease her .
#Text=She does n’t trust me ; she never has and she never will .
#Text=I do n’t know what I have done to set her against me , but ever since I can remember I have been looked at with tears .
#Text=The trouble is , ” he went on , giving a twist to his moustache , “ I ‘ ve been too absurdly docile .
#Text=I ‘ ve been sprawling all my days by the maternal fireside , and my dear mother has grown used to bullying me .
#Text=I ‘ ve made myself cheap ! If I ‘ m not in my bed by eleven o’clock , the girl is sent out to explore with a lantern .
#Text=When I think of it , I fairly despise my amiability .
#Text=It ‘ s rather a hard fate , to live like a saint and to pass for a sinner ! I should like for six months to lead Mrs. Hudson the life some fellows lead their mothers ! ”
#Text=“ Allow me to believe , ” said Rowland , “ that you would like nothing of the sort .
#Text=If you have been a good boy , do n’t spoil it by pretending you do n’t like it .
#Text=You have been very happy , I suspect , in spite of your virtues , and there are worse fates in the world than being loved too well .
#Text=I have not had the pleasure of seeing your mother , but I would lay you a wager that that is the trouble .

#Text=She is passionately fond of you , and her hopes , like all intense hopes , keep trembling into fears . ” Rowland , as he spoke , had an instinctive vision of how such a beautiful young fellow must be loved by his female relatives .
#Text=Roderick frowned , and with an impatient gesture , “ I do her justice , ” he cried .
#Text=“ May she never do me less ! ”
#Text=Then after a moment ’s hesitation , “ I ‘ ll tell you the perfect truth , ” he went on .
#Text=“ I have to fill a double place .
#Text=I have to be my brother as well as myself .
#Text=It ‘ s a good deal to ask of a man , especially when he has so little talent as I for being what he is not .
#Text=When we were both young together I was the curled darling .
#Text=I had the silver mug and the biggest piece of pudding , and I stayed in-doors to be kissed by the ladies while he made mud-pies in the garden and was never missed , of course .
#Text=Really , he was worth fifty of me ! When he was brought home from Vicksburg with a piece of shell in his skull , my poor mother began to think she had n’t loved him enough .
#Text=I remember , as she hung round my neck sobbing , before his coffin , she told me that I must be to her everything that he would have been .
#Text=I swore in tears and in perfect good faith that I would , but naturally I have not kept my promise .
#Text=I have been utterly different .
#Text=I have been idle , restless , egotistical , discontented .
#Text=I have done no harm , I believe , but I have done no good .
#Text=My brother , if he had lived , would have made fifty thousand dollars and put gas and water into the house .
#Text=My mother , brooding night and day on her bereavement , has come to fix her ideal in offices of that sort .
#Text=Judged by that standard I ‘ m nowhere ! ”
#Text=Rowland was at loss how to receive this account of his friend ’s domestic circumstances ; it was plaintive , and yet the manner seemed to him over-trenchant .
#Text=“ You must lose no time in making a masterpiece , ” he answered ; “ then with the proceeds you can give her gas from golden burners . ”
#Text=“ So I have told her ; but she only half believes either in masterpiece or in proceeds .
#Text=She can see no good in my making statues ; they seem to her a snare of the enemy .
#Text=She would fain see me all my life tethered to the law , like a browsing goat to a stake .
#Text=In that way I ‘ m in sight . ‘ It ‘ s a more regular occupation ! ’ that ‘ s all I can get out of her .
#Text=A more regular damnation !
#Text=Is it a fact that artists , in general , are such wicked men ?
#Text=I never had the pleasure of knowing one , so I could n’t confute her with an example .

#Text=She had the advantage of me , because she formerly knew a portrait-painter at Richmond , who did her miniature in black lace mittens ( you may see it on the parlor table ) , who used to drink raw brandy and beat his wife .
#Text=I promised her that , whatever I might do to my wife , I would never beat my mother , and that as for brandy , raw or diluted , I detested it .
#Text=She sat silently crying for an hour , during which I expended treasures of eloquence .
#Text=It ‘ s a good thing to have to reckon up one ’s intentions , and I assure you , as I pleaded my cause , I was most agreeably impressed with the elevated character of my own .
#Text=I kissed her solemnly at last , and told her that I had said everything and that she must make the best of it .
#Text=This morning she has dried her eyes , but I warrant you it is n’t a cheerful house .
#Text=I long to be out of it ! ”
